newsitem.title: GERMANY: Adidas says expects further steady growth.
newsitem.headline: Adidas says expects further steady growth.

text.p: German sportswear maker Adidas AG said on Tuesday that it expected "further steady growth" after reporting record third-quarter sales and earnings.
"Our business outlook, based on a 30 percent increase in our order backlog, is very positive," Adidas chief executive Robert Louis-Dreyfus said in a statement.
"We are expecting further steady growth for Adidas."

Adidas, best known for its three-stripe logo, said net sales for the third quarter rose 35 percent to 1.47 billion marks ($984.8 million) from 1.09 billion in the year-ago quarter. Net income rose 17 percent to 140 million marks from 120 million marks.

"We are pleased with our latest results which confirm the continuing success of the brand in the marketplace," he said. "It is another step forward towards realising our mission to become the best sports brand in the world."
Adidas, which is based in Herzogenaurach, said its apparel sales rose 45.5 percent while overall footwear sales rose 24.2 percent year-on-year growth.
Europe was still the engine behind Adidas' growth, with sales topping one billion marks for the first time in company history to 1.01 billion marks.
Sales in North America grew by an above-average 44 percent to 314 million marks from 218 million marks in the 1995 third quarter.

Net sales in the Asia-Pacific region grew to 119 million marks from 98 million marks, a year-on-year gain of 22 percent, while turnover in Latin America rose 17 percent to 28 million marks from 24 million marks.

For the first nine months of the year, Adidas said European sales rose to 2.53 billion marks from 1.91 billion marks in the year-ago period, while sales in North America rose by 27 percent and in Asia by 30 percent.
Adidas said its trade receivables rose 36 percent to 953 million marks as of September 30, which was slightly above the sales growth of 35 percent for the third quarter.
The company said almost one-third of the growth was due to the inclusion of the Italian joint venture on 1996 results.
Inventories rose by 36.2 percent to 828 million marks.
"The major reasons behind this increase are an increase in open orders and, to a lesser extent, the inclusion of new subsidiaries," Adidas said in a statement.
Order backlog remained strong, with the level as of September 30 for deliveries scheduled from October 1996 to March 1997 up 30 percent over year-ago levels.
In addition, Adidas said about 500,000 pairs of its new "Feet You Wear" shoes launched in the 1996 third quarter had been sold by the end of September.
It said future sales in different categories were up by a double-digit growth rate.
